My understanding of the power of annotation =
is that you can put all the
information related to a class in the same file=
:
- configuration management
- persistence
- tests
- etc.

This is just lik=
e pushing the limit of encapsulation to a higher level.

If you make a chan=
ge in the class, you can easily change accordingly all
related information =
through annotations.

However, not all that information is to be provided w=
ith the code.

So one can have a set tools that clean up the code (preproce=
ssing
annotations) before releasing it.

I just played a bit with apt and t=
he annotation API: it does not look
that complicated to do a preprocessor r=
emoving from the code all methods
annotated by junit annotations.
